clinical_study.brief_title: Reliability of Methods for Determining the Vibration Threshold
clinical_study.official_title: Reliability of Methods for Determining the Vibration Threshold That Triggers the Reflex

lead_sponsor.agency: Istanbul Physical Medicine Rehabilitation Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Istanbul Physical Medicine Rehabilitation Training and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: It is known that whole-body vibration (TVV) has beneficial neuromuscular effects such as muscle strength increase. These beneficial effects are explained by the muscular reflex response induced by TVV. Reflex latency measurement is frequently used in clinical and neurophysiological research. The latency of the reflex response induced by TVV is defined as the period between the onset of the vibration stimulus and the onset point of the spike in the EMG signal. Various methods have been reported to determine the threshold stimulus intensity at which the vibration stimulus activates the reflex response. In their study, Ritzman et al. accepted the lower point of the vibration platform as the threshold at which vibrational stimuli activate the reflex. In some studies, the threshold vibration stimulus intensity that activates the reflex response was determined by measuring the vibration platform thrust force, and in some studies, the vibration platform acceleration was measured. However, there is no scientific information about the reliability of these methods used to determine the vibration stimulus threshold. The aim of this research is to test the reliability of the methods based on the measurement of vibration platform position, thrust force, and acceleration used to determine the vibration stimulus threshold.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is an experimental study for method development; a self-controlled (single group) study. Ten healthy male or female subjects between the ages of 18-45 will be included in the study. After obtaining informed consent from the subjects, 30 Hz low amplitude (2 mm) vibration for 30 seconds will be applied on the PowerPlate Pro5 device to meet TVV. After three minutes of rest, two sets of TVV will be applied for test purposes. For the test TVV, vibration will be applied at 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50 Hz frequencies, each lasting 30 seconds, with low amplitude.
Vibration stimuli detected by using the position sensor, accelerometer, and force sensor fixed on the TVV platform will be recorded the Data acquisition (PowerLab data acquisition system (ADInstruments, Oxford, United Kingdom). Soleus EMG responses will be recorded using the superficial electrodes (Kendall Covidien). The sample rate for recordings will be 40KHz.
Latency calculation with Cumulative Average Method: It will be done separately for all three sensors. An 80-500 Hz band-pass filter and full-wave rectification will be applied to EMG recordings. The peak of reflex responses (spike) will be marked with the help of LabChart7 (ver 7.3.7, ADInstruments, Oxford, United Kingdom). According to this marked point, 75 ms back averaging process will be applied for each vibration frequency separately. With the back averaging process, separate sensor records and EMG records will be averaged. Then, the average of the five vibration frequencies will be calculated for the sensor recordings and EMG recordings. The point where the standard error is lowest in the sensor recordings will be determined as the "effective stimulation point", and the point where the standard error is the lowest in the EMG recordings will be determined as the "reflex response onset time". The difference between the effective stimulation points and the EMG starting point will be calculated as the "latency of the reflex response".

study_design_info.masking_description: With the cumulative average method, latency estimation will be made blindly.

primary_outcome.time_frame: A single point in time (1 day)
primary_outcome.description: Threshold vibration stimulus intensity that activates the reflex response

arm_group.description: The reflex response will be recorded during whole-body vibration.
